    RETURN TO ISSUEPREVPerspectiveNEXT

    Free Energy Methods in Drug Design: Prospects of “Alchemical Perturbation” in Medicinal Chemistry

    Miniperspective

    • Billy J. Williams-Noonan
      • , 
    • Elizabeth Yuriev*
      • , and 
    • David K. Chalmers*
    View Author Information
    Medicinal Chemistry, Monash Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Monash University, 381 Royal Parade, Parkville, Victoria 3052, Australia
    *E.Y.: e-mail, [email protected]
    *D.K.C.: e-mail, [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 3, 638–649
    Publication Date (Web):July 26, 2017

    Publication History

    • Received7 May 2017
    • Published online4 August 2017
    • Published inissue 8 February 2018
    https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.7b00681
    Copyright © 2017 American Chemical Society

    Get e-Alerts
    SUBJECTS:
    • Free energy,
    • Ligands,
    • Chemical calculations,
    • Screening assays,
    • Electron correlation
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Underpinning all drug discovery projects is the interaction between a drug and its target, usually a protein. Thus, improved methods for predicting the magnitude of protein–ligand interactions have the potential to improve the efficiency of drug development. In this review, we describe the principles of free energy methods used for the calculation of protein–ligand binding free energies, the challenges associated with these methods, and recent advances developed to address these difficulties. We then present case studies from 2005 to 2017, each demonstrating that alchemical free energy methods can assist rational drug design projects. We conclude that alchemical methods are becoming a feasible reality in medicinal chemistry research due to improved computational resources and algorithms and that alchemical free energy predictions methods are close to becoming a mainstream tool for medicinal chemists.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The hit to lead process in drug development commonly involves the synthesis of large numbers of individual compounds in an iterative process that aims to optimize compound potency and biopharmaceutical properties. When available, detailed structural information, such as can be obtained from X-ray crystal structures, can assist the design process by revealing how the ligand interacts with the protein and where a lead compound might be modified to create new or improved interactions. However, by itself, a structure of a protein–ligand complex does not directly provide information about the importance (strength) of each specific interaction or provide a quantitative estimate of how particular changes made to a ligand might alter affinity. Ultimately, the information that would best assist the medicinal chemist in the choice of the next synthetic target would be an (at least reasonably accurate) estimate of the compound affinity. Reliable estimates of compound binding properties prior to synthesis would both enable better selection of compounds for synthesis and reduce the amount of effort required to produce potent leads with appropriate biopharmaceutical properties.
    Dependable methods for the prediction of ligand binding poses and affinities remain a key goal of computational medicinal chemistry, and a wide variety of methods of varying quality are available, including docking,(1-3) the linear interaction energy (LIE)(4) and linear response approximation (LRA)(5) methods, molecular mechanics Poisson–Boltzmann (MM-PBSA) simulations,(6) and free energy perturbation (FEP)(7) and other related alchemical perturbation methods. In this review, we focus specifically on alchemical perturbation methods with unbiased and unaccelerated sampling and comment on their scope, accuracy, and reliability in medicinal chemistry. We complete this review with seven case studies from 2005 to 2017 to the expected scope and accuracy of alchemical calculations.(7)

    Free Energy of Ligand Binding

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The process of a small molecule ligand binding to a target macromolecule (for simplicity, we will assume that the target is a protein) is a reaction where the ligand is transferred from the free state in solution, where it interacts with the solvent, to the bound state, where it makes new, generally noncovalent, bonds to the protein as shown in Figure 1. The free and bound macrostates can be subdivided into collections of discrete microstates, different conformations and relative orientations of both the protein and the ligand.
    The partition function (Z) is a mathematical equation that characterizes the number and energies of microstates available to a thermodynamic system. A partition function can be constructed for a particular macrostate (e.g., x corresponds to “bound” or ‘free) as shown in eq 1;(8) here nx is the total number of microstates belonging to macrostate x, Ei is the internal energy of microstate i, kb is Boltzmann’s constant, and T is the temperature of the system in kelvin. The partition functions of the bound and free microstates can be used to obtain the free energy of binding using the relationship shown in eq 2.(9)(1)(2)
    Equations 1 and 2 encapsulate the physical properties required to computationally estimate the free energy of a ligand binding to a protein. To obtain these properties, we must be able to model the following:
    (1)

    Protein, ligand, and solvent structure and energies. This information is determined by the computational model of the molecular environment (usually a molecular mechanics force field).

    (2)

    The total number and energies of the free states, including the consideration of ligand conformations in solution, the “relaxed” state of the protein binding site, and interactions of ligand and binding site with solvent.

    (3)

    The total number and energies of the bound states, requiring accurate modeling of protein–ligand interactions and any changes in protein conformation that may occur upon ligand binding.

    Finding all the free and bound states of a protein–ligand system presents an enormous computational problem, but this is not actually required. The computational cost can be reduced by sampling only a subset of the available conformational space and by using this subset to estimate the partition function (eq 1). The computational requirements are reduced further by the fact that the low energy conformations make the largest contribution to the partition function, meaning that reasonable estimates for the partition function can be obtained even if the high-energy conformations are neglected.
    A wide variety of approaches for estimating binding free energies have been developed that, to some extent, neglect or approximate the factors set out in points 1–3 above. For example, end point approximation methods (e.g., LIE, LRA, MM-PBSA) compute approximate binding free energies by subtracting energies of the bound and free states.(4-6) These methods often overestimate the enthalpic benefit to ligand binding (by inadequately accounting for water movement) while underestimating the entropic penalty to binding (due to undersampling of the relevant conformers).(4-6) As another example, steered molecular dynamics (steered MD) can be used to create a biasing force that pulls the ligand from the receptor and measure an unbinding free energy. This approach generally undersamples the relevant protein–ligand states across the unbinding pathway, leading to errors in the computed binding free energy (ΔG).(10-13)

    Molecular Dynamics Simulations

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations model the movement of atoms and molecules within a system, most commonly using a molecular mechanics force field to compute the interactions within and between molecules (bonding, electrostatic, and van der Waals interactions).(14) MD is based on Newtonian principles, whereby atoms move in accordance with classical mechanical laws. In the drug discovery context, important applications of MD include exploration of low energy conformations of the protein–ligand complex and modeling the conformations of the ligand-free protein and the unbound ligand in solution. Accelerated or biased MD simulations can be used to improve conformational sampling or to drive simulations toward specific end points.(15) Other sampling techniques, such as Monte Carlo simulations,(16) can also be used to explore the conformational landscape.
    The quality of MD simulations is predominantly determined by the accuracy of the model used to calculate the structure and energetics of the molecular system of interest (i.e., the force field). Since the early days of molecular modeling, there have been steady and systematic improvements made to the force fields for biological macromolecules, resulting in the currently available, well-tested force fields such as GROMOS,(17) AMBER,(18, 19) and CHARMM,(20) which reproduce key features of biomolecule conformation and energetics.(21) However, obtaining or developing good quality force field parameters for novel small molecules that are compatible with the available biomolecular force fields is frequently problematic(22) and represents a common technical limitation to modeling protein–ligand complexes. Fortunately, this problem is being reduced through the active development of tools for the parametrization of small molecules, including the Automated Topology Builder (ATB)(23, 24) for the GROMOS force fields, the Antechamber package,(25) which creates Generalized Amber Force Field (GAFF)(26) parameters for small molecules compatible with existing Amber parameters, and the CGenFF package(27, 28) for CHARMM.
    Biomolecular MD simulations are typically set up so that the molecules of interest are surrounded by a model environment consisting mostly of water but also including appropriate buffer ions and possibly a lipid bilayer in the case of membrane-bound proteins. Simulations generally use periodic boundary conditions, meaning that each simulation cell is surrounded by multiple copies of the primary cell, which eliminates the presence of any boundary between the molecules in the simulation and surrounding vacuum. Such a vacuum–solvent interface is undesirable for a number of reasons, but particularly because it causes surface effects such as reordering of solvent and surface tension that do not represent the behavior of bulk solvent correctly. Figure 2 illustrates the case of a peptide in the primary cell (represented as a red surface) and nearby water atoms (represented as sticks) surrounded by identical replicate cells. This system uses a cubic periodic cell, although other space filling polyhedra such as the rhombic dodecahedron or cubic octahedron can be used. Although they provide an improved model of bulk solution, periodic boundary conditions do themselves introduce other types of artifacts into simulations, particularly if there are strong interactions between a molecule and its periodic neighbors.(29)
    During MD simulations, properties of state (temperature, pressure, volume, etc.) are regulated by the MD algorithm to maintain the system in a particular thermodynamic ensemble. Biomolecular simulations are most commonly performed using either the canonical or isothermal–isobaric thermodynamic ensemble.(30, 31) Both systems maintain a constant number of particles (no atoms are created or destroyed) and regulate temperature by an algorithm that models contact with a large heat bath (a thermostat). In the canonical ensemble, the system is of a fixed volume (the simulation cell is of fixed dimensions). In the isothermal–isobaric system a constant average pressure is maintained by varying the cell size under the control of a barostat algorithm.

    Steered Molecular Dynamics and Umbrella Sampling

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In principle, the free energy of a ligand-binding reaction can be derived from unbiased molecular dynamics simulations where the ligand is allowed to travel spontaneously from the solution to the binding site. Such simulations can be performed,(32) but in practice require very large numbers of long simulations to observe ligand binding events.(33) Generally, it is computationally much more efficient to restrict the freedom of the ligand and constrain it to follow a binding (or unbinding) pathway. Free energies of binding can be calculated from such constrained simulations provided the energetics of the applied constraint are taken into account.
    The conceptually most straightforward approach to calculating the free energy of ligand binding is to measure the attractive force between the ligand and protein as the ligand is pulled directly out of the binding site. From the measured relationship between force and displacement, the total work, or free energy of binding, can be derived. The plot of average potential energy versus displacement is known as the potential of mean force (PMF). One way to calculate the PMF is by steered MD, whereby a force is applied over the course of the simulation that pulls the ligand away from the protein (Figure 3A). The pathway out of the receptor must be explored for sufficient time to allow the system to reach equilibrium conditions throughout the pull trajectory. In practice, this often requires significant simulation time, and so steered MD is frequently conducted under nonequilibrium conditions. As a corrective measure, an equilibrium PMF can be derived from the nonequilibrium data using the Jarzynski relationship.(10-13) Alternatively, a more reliable PMF can be also be obtained using an enhanced sampling method known as “umbrella sampling”,(34) which uses a series of equilibrium simulations, each with the ligand restrained at fixed positions moving away from the binding pocket (Figure 3B).(13, 35, 36) Harmonic (parabolic) constraints are generally used (the origin of “umbrella” in the name), which force the ligand to sample the higher energy regions of the unbinding pathway that would otherwise not be sampled by an unconstrained simulation.(13, 35, 36) The complete PMF for the binding reaction is reassembled from the individual curves calculated from the discrete simulations using an approach such as the weighted histogram analysis method (WHAM).(37) Both steered MD and umbrella sampling are often used in ligand binding studies and provide good free energy estimates,(38) but care must be taken to avoid systematic errors that can arise from incomplete sampling of the available conformational space(39) or, in the case of umbrella sampling, poor overlap between the conformations sampled in adjacent simulations.(38, 40)

    Alchemical Transformations

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Free energy perturbation calculations are often (ironically) described as “alchemical” because they make a nonphysical transformation of one compound into a related chemical species, for example, the transformation of ethane into methanol (Figure 4A), or cause the “disappearance” of a molecule by conversion of normal atoms, which interact physically with the surrounding environment, into dummy atoms that make no intermolecular interactions and are invisible to the surrounding environment (Figure 4B). Simulations of the type shown in Figure 4A are used to determine the difference in free energy between the interaction of two molecules with the surrounding environment, for example, the difference in solvation energies of ethane and methanol. The conversion of a molecule into noninteracting dummy atoms, as shown in Figure 4B, enables the calculation of the difference in free energy between a molecule within a particular environment and the molecule in a vacuum.
    The free energy difference between states can be calculated using alchemical perturbation methods, where the ligand is progressively transformed from the initial to the final state over a number of discrete steps. In practice, the progression between states is characterized as a function of a variable (λ) which ranges between 0 (representing the initial state) and 1 (the final state). In the intermediate λ-states, the atomic properties (e.g., atomic partial charge and van der Waals interactions) are transformed smoothly (although not necessarily linearly) from those of the initial molecule to those of the final molecule such that there are no large free energy changes between adjacent steps. At each step, a molecular dynamics simulation is performed that must adequately sample the conformations available to the system and provide appreciable overlap with the conformations available to the simulations performed at the adjacent λ-state.(41)
    Having run simulations where one system is perturbed into another, a variety of methods are available to calculate the total free energy change, including the original “free energy perturbation” (FEP) approach devised by Zwanzig (1954).(42) In the literature today, a derivation of this method is commonly referred to as exponential averaging (DEXP or IEXP).(43) Other methods for the computation of the free energy difference between two states are thermodynamic integration (TI), the weighted histogram analysis method (WHAM), and the Bennett acceptance ratio (BAR) and its extension the multistate Bennett acceptance ratio (MBAR) approach.(43) Although the current literature often generalizes the term FEP to refer to perturbation methods in general, in this review we retain the term FEP for the original approach of Zwanzig and refer to all described statistical mechanics-based methods, including FEP, as “alchemical free energy methods” or “alchemical perturbation” techniques.
    In practice, the path taken from the initial to the final state and the number of intermediate steps (λ-states) can have a significant effect on the accuracy and efficiency of the alchemical perturbation calculation.(44, 45) Literature reports(46-54) suggest that in the bulk solvent, complete decoupling of a molecule requires between 10 and 30 intermediate λ-states. Similarly, between 30 and 50 λ-states are required when decoupling the ligand from the binding site,(46-54) although the number of λ-states needed varies depending on the complexity of the change between states A and B. Charged or flexible ligands may require more λ-states or longer simulations.

    Absolute and Relative Free Energies of Ligand Binding

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Free energy calculations can be performed in what is generally termed in the current literature as “absolute” or “relative” manners which are achieved using thermodynamic cycles such as those shown in Figure 5. We note that both approaches calculate a free energy difference between two states (ΔG or ΔΔG) and do not calculate the value of G itself, which would require calculation of the complete partition function which is possible only in very simple cases (see, for example, Skouteris et al.(55)). The absolute approach (Figure 5A) determines the change in free energy on moving a ligand from solution to the bound state (ΔGbind(a)) and requires simulations that progressively decouple the bound ligand from the binding site and the free ligand from the solvent. The decoupled bound ligand and the decoupled free ligand are equivalent, so the free energy of transfer between these two states is 0. To avoid delinquent wandering of the ligand as all interactions to the protein are turned off, it may be necessary to constrain the position of the decoupled ligand.(56) Alternatively, relative alchemical perturbation methods (Figure 5B) calculate the free energy difference between the binding of a pair of ligands, ΔΔGbind(a→b), by performing sets of simulations that transform one ligand into the other in the binding site and also in solution.

    Expected Accuracy of Alchemical Perturbation Methods

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    For a binding affinity value measured using a high quality experimental method, such as isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), the noise is said to be within 0.3–0.5 kcal/mol,(57) which suggests the RMSD from experiment for an absolute alchemical perturbation calculation cannot exceed this level of accuracy. Therefore, even alchemical calculations that are run for an extremely long time using supremely high-quality force are expected to deviate by at least 0.3 kcal/mol RMSD from experiment.
    Absolute free energy calculations often give binding free energies (ΔG) within 2–3 kcal/mol RMSD of experimental determinations for uncharged ligands and up to 4 kcal/mol RMSD for flexible or charged ligands.(7, 46-54) Comparatively, relative free energy calculations, which yield ΔΔG values, are typically more accurate(13, 58-67) because the initial and final states are generally similar (i.e., the perturbation might be performed between two molecules having a common core and differing in only a single functional group). Similarity between initial and final states reduces sampling errors and provides greater accuracy.
    When translating errors in free energy calculations to a corresponding effect on the dissociation equilibrium constant KD, one could question whether an RMSD of 2–3 kcal/mol from the experimental binding free energy is useful, given this level of error corresponds to quite large deviations in predicted KD.(9, 13) Indeed with errors of this magnitude, it is likely that the rank order of a series of ligands may not be reliably predicted using alchemical methods.(57)
    There are a number of sources of error in perturbation methods including, but not limited to, the quality of the force field parameters used, the treatment of electrostatic interactions, incomplete sampling, and methodological simplifications. Often, the largest sources of error associated with alchemical free energy methods come down to inadequacies in the force field and suboptimal sampling of the energy landscape between states A and B. In the case of charged ligands, it has been shown that the free energy of binding is influenced by a variety of factors, including the size and shape of the periodic cell, the treatment of electrostatic interactions, and the presence of counterions.(68, 69) Error is also derived from statistical noise and errors intrinsic to the computational models used to represent the system.(57) In addition to the inherent calculation errors, alchemical free energy methods suffer from time-related limitations. Specifically, protein conformational changes and ligand transformations between binding modes generally take much longer than the alchemical perturbation calculations themselves. Therefore, the alchemical free energy calculation may not accurately measure the change in free energy between state A and state B in instances where there is a high degree of protein movement(38, 47, 51, 70-73) or where ligand behavior in the binding site is not sufficiently sampled. It may not be possible to simulate even small protein conformational changes or multiple ligand binding modes within the time span of a few nanoseconds per λ-state. Alchemical calculations in these cases can result in erroneous values for binding free energies.(74, 75)
    Despite the above limitations, alchemical free energy methods are still a powerful tool that can be highly effective when combined with current lead optimization methods.(9, 13) Shirts et al.(13) have proposed that binding free energy predictions within 2–3 kcal/mol RMSD from experiment can still significantly reduce the synthetic effort required for lead optimization. In a thought experiment, they showed that screening molecules based on simulations with 2.0 kcal/mol RMSD from experiment would reduce the number of compounds that had to be synthesized to provide a 10-fold dissociation constant improvement by a factor of 3.(13) With higher accuracy (lower RMSD from experiment), the average number of compounds needed to produce a 10-fold dissociation constant improvement decreases even further.(13)
    Undersampling in relative alchemical free energy calculations, and the ensuing lack of convergence, produces errors in the calculated free energy of interconversion between molecules (ΔΔG). This error is termed “hysteresis”. Hysteresis errors (ξ) become evident in cases that contain a closed cycle that does not sum to zero, such as the simple system shown in Figure 6 (A → B, B → C, C → A). Thus, closed cycles provide an effective means of verifying the accuracy of a relative alchemical perturbation calculation, since the sum of ΔΔGA→B, ΔΔGB→C, and ΔΔGC→A should be 0. If the sum of these three binding affinity differences has a nonzero value, then the residual error (if statistically significant) can be corrected for. In this simple case, the corrective term for each “edge” is ξ/3. In more complex cases containing multiple, interconnected cycles, the algorithm proposed by Wang et al. can be used to eliminate the hysteresis.(76)

    Alchemical Free Energy Methods for Binding Energy Determination: Success Stories

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Here we present selected studies taken from the period 2005 to 2017 that implement relative or absolute free energy calculations to predict protein–ligand binding free energies. (Table 1). We focus specifically on work that utilizes the alchemical methods already described, leaving aside a number of possible variations in methodology (although they may be useful and widely applicable). We do not cover applications of implicit models(77) such as the generalized Born solvent model. Alchemical free energy methods have also been employed in protein mutation studies,(78-81) where one residue is alchemically transformed to another, to determine what biological effect this would have, and variations on these methods have been successful in a medicinal chemistry context.(82, 83) Further, one-step perturbation methods where the kinetic and potential energies of the system are not expressed as a function of λ have also demonstrated moderate to high success.(84, 85) Monte Carlo methods can be used to sample the molecular structures rather than MD.(86-90) Finally, we do not discuss quantum mechanical methods, which are arguably more accurate than molecular mechanics-based MD, but they are even slower to compute due to the increased complexity involved.(91-93)
    Table 1. A Selection of Recent Alchemical Perturbation Studies
    yearref (first author)alchemical methodatarget proteinno. ligandsbno. perturbationschysteresis correctiondRMSDe (kcal/mol)Rfρg
    2005Fujitani(94)AbsFKBP88 ∼3.2h ∼1.0
    2005Archontis(95)Relglycogen phosphorylase32low0.90  
    2006, 2008Steinbrecher(72, 96)Relhuman neutrophil elastase43 1.00  
    2006Jayachandran(47)AbsFKBP88 1.600.720.88
    2007Mobley(38)AbsT4 lysozyme1326low1.890.8 
    2012Palma(65)RelO-methyltransferase1144med0.33i  
    2013Rogers(97)RelMshB33    
    2013Wang(76)RelCDK21618high0.640.82 
    2014Lee(98)RelGSK3β1817 1.10j  
    2015Wang(67)Relmultiple199330high1.100.75 
    2015Steinbrecher(99)Relmultiple96157med1.140.81 
    2016Aldeghi(100)AbsBRD41144 0.800.840.82
    2016Ciorda(101)RelBACE15062high 0.67- 0.83 
    2016Eelke(102)Relfour GPCRs5090high 0.620.55
    2016Ioannidis(103)Relinfluenza M21314 0.73–0.940.76–0.92 
    2017Bhati(104)Relmultiple∼5055low0.80–1.400.80–0.900.80–0.91
    a

    An absolute (Abs) or relative (Rel) alchemical perturbation protocol was used.

    b

    Number of ligands in study.

    c

    Number of perturbations used in the study.

    d

    The possibility of nonconvergence was corrected using low, medium, or high effort corrective measures.

    e

    The RMSD of the predicted values from equivalent high-quality experimental ones.

    f

    Pearson’s coefficient of determination versus experiment.

    g

    Spearman’s rank order correlation coefficient versus experimental data.

    h

    A linear regression was performed between predicted and experimental data with a vertical shift of 3.2 kcal/mol, and it was found that this offset best explained the data. The rank-order of the compounds was correctly predicted despite this offset.

    i

    Only three experimental differences were used in the generation of this value, and as such, it may not be reliable.

    j

    Only one experimental difference was used in the generation of this value, and as such, it may not be reliable.(98)

    Table 1 presents a set of alchemical free energy studies taken from the recent literature ordered from oldest to most recent. Although this list is not exhaustive, it demonstrates the improvement in alchemical perturbation accuracy as methods, computing power, and models are being improved. Alchemical free energy studies from the period 2005 to around 2007 generally use only small numbers of ligands with a single target receptor. By comparison, a single 2015 report(67) investigates the binding of 199 ligands, each as an inhibitor of one of eight targets, and replicates their binding affinities with high accuracy.

    “Computation of the Binding Affinities of Catechol-O-methyltransferase Inhibitors: Multisubstate Relative Free Energy Calculations” (2012)

    Catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) is an enzyme that promotes the transfer of a methyl group from S-adenosyl-l-methionine (SAM) to a variety of catecholamines and catechol-estrogens.(65, 105) COMT is implicated in a variety of metabolic and psychiatric disease states and is the target of several drugs in clinical use. Palma et al. employed relative alchemical free energy techniques to calculate the difference in binding affinities between catechol and two known inhibitors of COMT: tolcapone and opicapone, the latter of which has extremely high, subpicomolar affinity.(65) Opicapone was recently investigated in a phase III clinical trial and showed a significantly higher response rate than placebo.(8)
    The authors began with catechol bound in complex with a binding site magnesium ion and perturbed the catechol structure over four steps to produce tolcapone. Catechol was also perturbed over seven steps to give the inhibitor opicapone.(65) The total perturbation map starting from catechol and diverging into these two inhibitors is illustrated in Figure 7. Modeling of bound tolcapone, opicapone, and the intermediate alchemical points is complicated by the possibility of multiple alternate binding poses, caused by rotation about dihedral angles ϕ and θ (Figure 7). Molecular docking and molecular dynamics simulations were used to identify four feasible bound poses for opicapone. Two putative substates of tolcapone were found using a similar rationale. Subsequently, the free energy calculations were carried over four paths, progressing from catechol to each of the putative binding poses. ΔΔG values for the conversion of catechol to tolcapone and opicapone were generated for each pose, and a Boltzmann weighted average of the energies of the relevant substates (two different torsion angles) was generated to give overall ΔΔG values for each step of the alchemical route. The predicted ΔΔG values were within 0.5 kcal/mol RMSD of experimentally determined free energy differences: this prediction was assessed by the authors to be at the theoretical limit of accuracy.

    “Accurate and Reliable Relative Ligand Binding Potency in Prospective Drug Discovery by Way of a Modern Free-Energy Calculation Protocol and Force Field” (2015)

    This large study by Wang et al.(67) gathers alchemical calculations for the binding of ligands to eight proteins involved in disease pathogenesis: BACE, CDK2, JNK1, MCL1, p38, PTP1B, thrombin, and Tyk2. A grand total of 330 relative alchemical free energy calculations using 199 ligands were performed, whereby one single ligand was often perturbed more than once into different ligands, with multiple permutations between pairs of ligands. A range of technical approaches were used to improve the accuracy and throughput of calculations, including enhanced sampling, a refined force field, and GPU-based acceleration of calculations. The overall methodology was termed FEP+.
    FEP+ generates ligand topologies using the LOMAP approach,(106) which identifies the maximum common substructure (MCSS) of two or more molecules and generates a topology based on the common features.(107) An improved version of the OPLS force field was implemented, producing lower RSMD error from experiment for solvation free energies than analogous force fields. Each simulation was typically performed for 5 ns per λ-state for 12 λ-states using free energy perturbation-replica exchange with solute tempering (FEP-REST). The REST algorithm(76) runs concurrently with the production run and works by artificially decreasing the potential energy in the binding site, without altering the kinetic energy. This technique thus creates a “hot” region that allows for smoother, more rapid transitions between different possible binding modes, thereby reducing sampling times.
    The FEP+ protocol produced RMSDs of 1.1 kcal/mol relative to experimental binding affinity differences. The predicted and experimental binding affinities correlated with a Pearson’s R of 0.75, across all targets. For the separate targets utilized, in the best case scenario, the RMSD from experiment was 0.93 kcal/mol, while in the worst case scenario, the RMSD error was 1.41 kcal/mol, suggesting a consistent level accuracy across the different systems. A significant improvement in the result accuracy was attributed to improvements in the ligand force field.
    This study(67) is unusual in that it reports results from two prospective studies, where compounds have been synthesized based on alchemical perturbation calculations. Historically, alchemical free energy papers have focused primarily on retrospective predictions of binding free energies and do not usually provide analysis of the use of prospective predictions in the design of novel compounds. Although full details of the synthesized compounds are not provided and the analysis is brief, the authors report that the free energy predictions are in general reliable and that the use of alchemical perturbation calculations substantially enhances the number of synthesized potent compounds. Similarly, success at prospectively predicting protein–ligand binding free energies was more recently reported in a similar study utilizing the FEP+ protocol for ligands binding to several GPCRs.(102)

    “Accurate Binding Free Energy Predictions in Fragment Optimization” (2015)

    In this retrospective analysis, Steinbrecher et al. applied the FEP+ methodology to multiple chemical series developed in fragment-based drug design programs. This paper aggregates data from the binding of 200 fragment-based inhibitors of one of eight proteins: lysozyme, DNA ligase, Mcl-1, MUP-I, LDH, JAK-2, HSP90, and p38.(99) In each case, good quality X-ray crystal structures were available. The authors replicated the binding affinities of each ligand to their respective targets within an RMSD of 1.14 kcal/mol from experiment with a Pearson’s R2 of 0.65 using relative alchemical perturbation. Alchemical free energy calculations were shown to be much more accurate than docking and MM-GBSA, which yielded a Pearson’s R2 between predicted and experimental binding affinities of 0.35 and 0.41, respectively. Hysteresis was shown to be statistically nonsignificant using the thermodynamic cycle closure approach used in the previous study(67) and was not corrected for. In this way, the authors demonstrated that relative alchemical perturbation calculations performed using as little as 3–5 ns of simulation time per λ-state can be highly reliable, thereby adding to the pool of evidence that alchemical free energy methods are fast becoming ready for mainstream use in medicinal chemistry.

    “Accurate Calculation of the Absolute Free Energy of Binding for Drug Molecules” (2016)

    Bromodomain proteins (BRDs) recognize the N-acetylated lysine residues present on the histone proteins that complex with DNA.(108) Some subtypes of BRD have been linked to a variety of epigenetic disease states, including the incidence of multiple strains of cancer.(108) Aldeghi et al. used absolute alchemical perturbation calculations to investigate the binding of a series of 11 inhibitors to BRD4, which is involved in the aberrant recognition and subsequent transcription of genes that produce apoptotic proteins.(100) Absolute binding free energies were obtained for crystallographic BRD4-ligand complexes as well as for docked structures. This was done to ascertain the importance of using a high-quality starting pose in obtaining an accurate absolute free energy. A total of 42 λ-states were used in each simulation, and each was run for 10 ns, with 5 ns of data collection, all after a 1 ns equilibration phase.
    For calculations starting with the docked pose, the overall RMSD from experiment was 1.4 kcal/mol, and correlation coefficients between predicted and experimental binding energies were Pearson’s R = 0.77 and Spearman’s ρ = 0.72, indicating a high level of predictive power. When starting from the crystal structure pose, the RMSD from experiment for the predictions improved to a 0.8 kcal/mol, and correlations were stronger, with R = 0.84 and ρ = 0.82, suggesting that, at least in this instance, the better the quality of the starting ligand pose is, the more accurate the result. These results reported by Aldeghi et al.(100) are better than those obtained typically when using absolute alchemical perturbation methods, with more than 64% of the variance in the rank order of the tested ligands explained by the model in the best-case scenario and with the rest of the predictions being close to experimental values. This level of accuracy is quite rare for absolute free energies. Indeed it is generally more common for a relative free energy calculation to be this accurate, given the dynamic range of binding affinities being tested is quite broad.(58-67)

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The papers discussed above clearly show that alchemical perturbation calculations have now reached a stage where they can be practically applied within drug development programs. In the most recent studies, alchemical free energy methods have been applied to large data sets with throughput that is sufficiently fast for practical application to compound design (multiple alchemical calculations per day). All of the reports above suggest that alchemical free energy methods are accurate, reliable, and robust, with relative alchemical perturbation methods being most concordant with experiment. Of the papers cited above, those with the best accuracy report results within 0.8–1.1 kcal/mol of experiment.(67, 99, 100) One significant limitation of the current literature is that nearly all reports describe work that has been carried out in a retrospective manner, where ligand affinities are known and the binding conformations have usually been determined by X-ray crystallography. The prospective use of computational modeling is generally more difficult than retrospective analysis, and there is clearly a need for further evaluation of prospective studies such as that by Wang et al.(67) From a technical point of view, there remains a definite need for more automated tools to set up and analyze alchemical free energy calculations so as to reduce the technical demands of these calculations and more readily allow their incorporation into the mainstream medicinal chemistry workflow. Improved software tools are currently being developed in commercial packages,(67, 99, 109) and it is evident that there is a definite movement toward making alchemical free energy methods a more mainstream tool that requires less technical expertise.
    Although the arrival of free energy calculations in medicinal chemistry has been predicted for more than 20 years,(110) we leave the reader with the perspective that the widespread application of alchemical methods within medicinal chemistry programs is truly close. Over the past 2 decades, there have been great advances in the computer hardware and software necessary to perform complex free energy calculations and the development of sophisticated protein expression and crystallography methods that can provide good starting models for prospective calculations. Practical application of free energy methods for medicinal chemistry has been demonstrated in several of the papers discussed above, and the number of papers reporting the use of free energy calculations for large numbers of compounds is increasing. The current limitations on more widespread use perhaps lie more in aspects of practical implementation than by the technical limitations of the method. We expect that the take-up of free energy modeling in medicinal chemistry will be further encouraged by good quality reports of the use of free energy calculations in a prospective manner.

    The authors declare no competing financial interest.

      Yuriev, E.; Agostino, M.; Ramsland, P. A. Challenges and advances in computational docking: 2009 in review J. Mol. Recognit. 2011, 24, 149– 164 DOI: 10.1002/jmr.1077
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Challenges and advances in computational docking: 2009 in review
      Yuriev, Elizabeth; Agostino, Mark; Ramsland, Paul A.
      Journal of Molecular Recognition (2011), 24 (2), 149-164CODEN: JMORE4; ISSN:0952-3499. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. Docking is a computational technique that places a small mol. (ligand) in the binding site of its macromol. target (receptor) and ests. its binding affinity. This review addresses methodol. developments that have occurred in the docking field in 2009, with a particular focus on the more difficult, and sometimes controversial, aspects of this promising computational discipline. These developments aim to address the main challenges of docking: receptor representation (such aspects as structural waters, side chain protonation, and, most of all, flexibility (from side chain rotation to domain movement)), ligand representation (protonation, tautomerism and stereoisomerism, and the effect of input conformation), as well as accounting for solvation and entropy of binding. This review is strongly focused on docking advances in the context of drug design, specifically in virtual screening and fragment-based drug design. Copyright © 2010 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXisV2jsb8%253D&md5=214fb8189f4bb43675893ac6bdedf51d
    2. 2
      Yuriev, E.; Ramsland, P. A. Latest developments in molecular docking: 2010–2011 in review J. Mol. Recognit. 2013, 26, 215– 239 DOI: 10.1002/jmr.2266
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Latest developments in molecular docking: 2010-2011 in review
      Yuriev, Elizabeth; Ramsland, Paul A.
      Journal of Molecular Recognition (2013), 26 (5), 215-239CODEN: JMORE4; ISSN:0952-3499. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. The aim of docking is to accurately predict the structure of a ligand within the constraints of a receptor binding site and to correctly est. the strength of binding. We discuss, in detail, methodol. developments that occurred in the docking field in 2010 and 2011, with a particular focus on the more difficult, and sometimes controversial, aspects of this promising computational discipline. The main developments in docking in this period, covered in this review, are receptor flexibility, solvation, fragment docking, postprocessing, docking into homol. models, and docking comparisons. Several new, or at least newly invigorated, advances occurred in areas such as nonlinear scoring functions, using machine-learning approaches. This review is strongly focused on docking advances in the context of drug design, specifically in virtual screening and fragment-based drug design. Where appropriate, we refer readers to exemplar case studies. Copyright © 2013 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

      Lohning, A.; Levonis, S.; Williams-Noonan, B.; Schweiker, S. A practical guide to molecular docking and homology modelling for medicinal chemists Curr. Top. Med. Chem. 2017, 17, 2023– 2040 DOI: 10.2174/1568026617666170130110827

      3
      A Practical Guide to Molecular Docking and Homology Modelling for Medicinal Chemists
      Lohning, Anna E.; Levonis, Stephan M.; Williams-Noonan, Billy; Schweiker, Stephanie S.
      Current Topics in Medicinal Chemistry (Sharjah, United Arab Emirates) (2017), 17 (18), 2023-2040CODEN: CTMCCL; ISSN:1568-0266. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Elucidating details of the relationship between mol. structure and a particular biol. end point is essential for successful, rational drug discovery. Mol. docking is a widely accepted tool for lead identification however, navigating the intricacies of the software can be daunting. Our objective was therefore to provide a step-by-step guide for those interested in incorporating contemporary basic mol. docking and homol. modeling into their design strategy. Three mol. docking programs, AutoDock4, SwissDock and Surflex-Dock, were compared in the context of a case study where a set of steroidal and non-steroidal ligands were docked into the human androgen receptor (hAR) using both rigid and flexible target atoms. Metrics for comparison included how well each program predicted the X-ray structure orientation via root mean square deviation (rmsd), predicting known actives via ligand ranking and comparison to biol. data where available. Benchmarking metrics were discussed in terms of identifying accurate and reliable results. For cases where no three dimensional structure exists, we provided a practical example for creating a homol. model using Swiss-Model. Results showed an rmsd between X-ray ligands from wild-type and mutant receptors and docked poses were 4.15Å and 0.83Å (SwissDock), 2.69Å and 8.80Å (AutoDock4) and 0.39Å and 0.71Å (Surflex-Dock) resp. Surflex-Dock performed consistently well in pose prediction (less than 2Å) while Auto- Dock4 predicted known active non-steroidal antiandrogens most accurately. Introducing flexibility into target atoms produced the largest degree of change in ligand ranking in Surflex-Dock. We produced a viable homol. model of the P2X1 purireceptor for subsequent docking anal.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVShtr3J&md5=5dfe7ec9d9b9756e07b7cb04fee69145

      Aqvist, J.; Marelius, J. The linear interaction energy method for predicting ligand binding free energies Comb. Chem. High Throughput Screening 2001, 4, 613– 626 DOI: 10.2174/1386207013330661
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      The linear interaction energy method for predicting ligand binding free energies
      Aqvist, Johan; Marelius, John
      Combinatorial Chemistry and High Throughput Screening (2001), 4 (8), 613-626CODEN: CCHSFU; ISSN:1386-2073. (Bentham Science Publishers)
      An overview of the simplified linear interaction energy (LIE) method for calcn. of ligand binding free energies is given. This method is based on force field estns. of the receptor-ligand interactions and thermal conformational sampling. A notable feature is that the binding energetics can be predicted by considering only the intermol. interactions between the ligand and receptor. The approxns. behind this approach are examd. and different parameterizations of the model are discussed. In general, LIE type of methods appear particularly useful for computational drug lead optimization.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xks1Oktg%253D%253D&md5=53d20d4d9bfe7f03780d5e280d8c484d
    5. 5
      Makri, N. The linear response approximation and its lowest order corrections: An influence functional approach J. Phys. Chem. B 1999, 103, 2823– 2829 DOI: 10.1021/jp9847540
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      The Linear Response Approximation and Its Lowest Order Corrections: An Influence Functional Approach
      Makri, Nancy
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (1999), 103 (15), 2823-2829CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1089-5647. (American Chemical Society)
      A cumulant expansion of the influence functional entering the path integral representation of the reduced d. matrix is presented. Truncation of the expansion at the quadratic terms allows mapping of a many-body environment onto an effective harmonic model with the same force autocorrelation function, recovering the conventional linear response limit. It is shown that the latter becomes exact in the thermodn. limit if the bath consists of independent modes coupled to the system via coeffs. that scale appropriately with the size of the bath. Low-order correction terms to the linear response approxn. are found to be given by multitime correlation functions of the force exerted by the bath on the system. Within a classical approxn., such correction terms can be obtained from mol. dynamics calcns. and incorporated in the path integral, which can be evaluated by means of iterative procedures. Numerical calcns. on an intrinsically nonlinear bath of two-level systems confirm the above behaviors and indicate that the deviations from the linear response approxn. are more significant at low temps. where quantum mech. effects play an important role to the bath dynamics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXitVags70%253D&md5=bf3eae88c2de1d43225304f77e24c441
    6. 6
      Hou, T.; Wang, J.; Li, Y.; Wang, W. Assessing the performance of the MM/PBSA and MM/GBSA methods. 1. The accuracy of binding free energy calculations based on molecular dynamics simulations J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2011, 51, 69– 82 DOI: 10.1021/ci100275a
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Assessing the Performance of the MM/PBSA and MM/GBSA Methods. 1. The Accuracy of Binding Free Energy Calculations Based on Molecular Dynamics Simulations
      Hou, Tingjun; Wang, Junmei; Li, Youyong; Wang, Wei
      Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling (2011), 51 (1), 69-82CODEN: JCISD8; ISSN:1549-9596. (American Chemical Society)
      The Mol. Mechanics/Poisson-Boltzmann Surface Area (MM/PBSA) and the Mol. Mechanics/Generalized Born Surface Area (MM/GBSA) methods calc. binding free energies for macromols. by combining mol. mechanics calcns. and continuum solvation models. To systematically evaluate the performance of these methods, the authors report here an extensive study of 59 ligands interacting with six different proteins. First, the authors explored the effects of the length of the mol. dynamics (MD) simulation, ranging from 400 to 4800 ps, and the solute dielec. const. (1, 2, or 4) on the binding free energies predicted by MM/PBSA. The following three important conclusions could be obsd.: (1) MD simulation length has an obvious impact on the predictions, and longer MD simulation is not always necessary to achieve better predictions. (2) The predictions are quite sensitive to the solute dielec. const., and this parameter should be carefully detd. according to the characteristics of the protein/ligand binding interface. (3) Conformational entropy often show large fluctuations in MD trajectories, and a large no. of snapshots are necessary to achieve stable predictions. Next, the authors evaluated the accuracy of the binding free energies calcd. by three Generalized Born (GB) models. The authors found that the GB model developed by Onufriev and Case was the most successful model in ranking the binding affinities of the studied inhibitors. Finally, the authors evaluated the performance of MM/GBSA and MM/PBSA in predicting binding free energies. The authors' results showed that MM/PBSA performed better in calcg. abs., but not necessarily relative, binding free energies than MM/GBSA. Considering its computational efficiency, MM/GBSA can serve as a powerful tool in drug design, where correct ranking of inhibitors is often emphasized.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVyrsrrK&md5=b9f5b7fab70a6cc76b115d202d718f87

      Shirts, M. R.; Mobley, D. L.; Chodera, J. D. Alchemical free energy calculations: ready for prime time? Annu. Rep. Comput. Chem. 2007, 3, 41– 59 DOI: 10.1016/S1574-1400(07)03004-6
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Alchemical free energy calculations: Ready for prime time?
      Shirts, Michael R.; Mobley, David L.; Chodera, John D.
      Annual Reports in Computational Chemistry (2007), 3 (), 41-59CODEN: ARCCC3; ISSN:1574-1400. (Elsevier B.V.)
      This review discusses the recent literature on methodol. improvements in free energy computation that have made this possible. It focuses on current research using the most common rigorously exact method, that of "alchem." transformation. In an alchem. transformation, a chem. species is transformed into another via a pathway of nonphys. (alchem.) states.

      Steinbrecher, T.; Labahn, A. Towards accurate free energy calculations in ligand protein-binding studies Curr. Med. Chem. 2010, 17, 767– 785 DOI: 10.2174/092986710790514453
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Towards accurate free energy calculations in ligand protein-binding studies
      Steinbrecher, Thomas; Labahn, Andreas
      Current Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 17 (8), 767-785CODEN: CMCHE7; ISSN:0929-8673. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Cells contain a multitude of different chem. reaction paths running simultaneously and quite independently next to each other. This amazing feat is enabled by mol. recognition, the ability of biomols. to form stable and specific complexes with each other and with their substrates. A better understanding of this process, i.e. of the kinetics, structures and thermodn. properties of biomol. binding, would be invaluable in the study of biol. systems. In addn., as the mode of action of many pharmaceuticals is based upon their inhibition or activation of biomol. targets, predictive models of small mol. receptor binding are very helpful tools in rational drug design. Since the goal here is normally to design a new compd. with a high inhibition strength, one of the most important thermodn. properties is the binding free energy ΔG0. The prediction of binding consts. has always been one of the major goals in the field of computational chem., because the ability to reliably assess a hypothetical compd.'s binding properties without having to synthesize it first would save a tremendous amt. of work. The different approaches to this question range from fast and simple empirical descriptor methods to elaborate simulation protocols aimed at putting the computation of free energies onto a solid foundation of statistical thermodn. While the later methods are still not suited for the screenings of thousands of compds. that are routinely performed in computational drug design studies, they are increasingly put to use for the detailed study of protein ligand interactions. This review will focus on mol. mechanics force field based free energy calcns. and their application to the study of protein ligand interactions. After a brief overview of other popular methods for the calcn. of free energies, we will describe recent advances in methodol. and a variety of exemplary studies of mol. dynamics simulation based free energy calcns.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjs1Kkurw%253D&md5=e06994fb21a04ba7bbc572daa97c91b6

      Jarzynski, C. Nonequilibrium equality for free energy differences Phys. Rev. Lett. 1997, 78, 2690– 2693 DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.78.2690
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Nonequilibrium equality for free energy differences
      Jarzynski, C.
      Physical Review Letters (1997), 78 (14), 2690-2693CODEN: PRLTAO; ISSN:0031-9007. (American Physical Society)
      An expression is derived for the equil. free energy difference between two configurations of a system, in terms of an ensemble of finite-time measurements of the work performed in parametrically switching from one configuration to the other. Two well-known identities emerge as limiting cases of this result.

      Hummer, G.; Szabo, A. Free energy reconstruction from nonequilibrium single-molecule pulling experiments Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001, 98, 3658– 3661 DOI: 10.1073/pnas.071034098
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Free energy reconstruction from nonequilibrium single-molecule pulling experiments
      Hummer, Gerhard; Szabo, Attila
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2001), 98 (7), 3658-3661CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Laser tweezers and at. force microscopes are increasingly used to probe the interactions and mech. properties of individual mols. Unfortunately, using such time-dependent perturbations to force rare mol. events also drives the system away from equil. Nevertheless, we show how equil. free energy profiles can be extd. rigorously from repeated nonequil. force measurements on the basis of an extension of Jarzynski's remarkable identity between free energies and the irreversible work.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXis1Kitbk%253D&md5=b8b557f038efd3d60f9a97881636c120

    15. 15
      Bernardi, R. C.; Melo, M. C. R.; Schulten, K. Enhanced sampling techniques in molecular dynamics simulations of biological systems Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gen. Subj. 2015, 1850, 872– 877 DOI: 10.1016/j.bbagen.2014.10.019
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Enhanced sampling techniques in molecular dynamics simulations of biological systems
      Bernardi, Rafael C.; Melo, Marcelo C. R.; Schulten, Klaus
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (2015), 1850 (5), 872-877CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Mol. dynamics has emerged as an important research methodol. covering systems to the level of millions of atoms. However, insufficient sampling often limits its application. The limitation is due to rough energy landscapes, with many local min. sepd. by high-energy barriers, which govern the biomol. motion. In the past few decades methods have been developed that address the sampling problem, such as replica-exchange mol. dynamics, metadynamics and simulated annealing. Here the authors present an overview over theses sampling methods in an attempt to shed light on which should be selected depending on the type of system property studied. Enhanced sampling methods have been employed for a broad range of biol. systems and the choice of a suitable method is connected to biol. and phys. characteristics of the system, in particular system size. While metadynamics and replica-exchange mol. dynamics are the most adopted sampling methods to study biomol. dynamics, simulated annealing is well suited to characterize very flexible systems. The use of annealing methods for a long time was restricted to simulation of small proteins; however, a variant of the method, generalized simulated annealing, can be employed at a relatively low computational cost to large macromol. complexes. Mol. dynamics trajectories frequently do not reach all relevant conformational substates, for example those connected with biol. function, a problem that can be addressed by employing enhanced sampling algorithms. This article is part of a Special Issue entitled Recent developments of mol. dynamics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvVanurbN&md5=44e3ac1aa042c35ee08aa86a6a63e78e
    16. 16
      Harrison, R. L. Introduction to monte carlo simulation AIP Conf. Proc. 2010, 1204, 17– 21 DOI: 10.1063/1.3295638
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Introduction To Monte Carlo Simulation
      Harrison Robert L
      AIP conference proceedings (2010), 1204 (), 17-21 ISSN:0094-243X.
      This paper reviews the history and principles of Monte Carlo simulation, emphasizing techniques commonly used in the simulation of medical imaging.

    17. 17
      Reif, M. M.; Hunenberger, P. H.; Oostenbrink, C. New interaction parameters for charged amino acid side chains in the GROMOS force field J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2012, 8, 3705– 3723 DOI: 10.1021/ct300156h
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      New Interaction Parameters for Charged Amino Acid Side Chains in the GROMOS Force Field
      Reif, Maria M.; Huenenberger, Philippe H.; Oostenbrink, Chris
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2012), 8 (10), 3705-3723CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      A GROMOS force-field parameter set 54A8 is developed, which is based on the latest 54A7 set and involves a recalibration of the nonbonded interaction parameters for the charged amino acid side chains, based on ionic side chain analogs. After a thorough anal. of the available exptl. data, conventional hydration free energies for the ammonium; mono-, di-, tri-, and tetramethyl-ammonium; formate; acetate; propanoate; imidazolium; and guanidinium ions are combined with a std. abs. intrinsic proton hydration free energy ΔGhyd-[Hg+] = -1100 kJ·mol-1 to yield abs. intrinsic single-ion hydration free energies serving as exptl. target data. The raw hydration free energies calcd. from atomistic simulations are affected by electrostatic and finite-size artifacts, and corrections are applied to reach methodol. independence prior to comparison with these exptl. values. Except for monomethyl-ammonium, ions with parameters derived directly from the 54A7 force field considerably underestimate (ammonium, formate, acetate, propanoate, guanidinium) or overestimate (di-, tri-, and tetramethyl-ammonium; imidazolium) the magnitude of the intrinsic hydration free energy, the largest deviation affecting the acetate ion (40.0 kJ·mol-1). After reparameterization into 54A8, the mean and maximal abs. deviations between simulated and exptl. data over the set of 10 ions are reduced from 23.1 and 40.0 kJ·mol-1, resp., to 1.8 and 6.3 kJ·mol-1, resp. Although the 54A7 and 54A8 parameter sets differ significantly in terms of the hydration free energies of the ions considered, other properties such as ion-water radial distribution functions and ion-ion potentials of mean force appear to be only moderately sensitive to this change. These properties are similar for the two sets and, in the case of the ion-water radial distribution functions, in good agreement with available exptl. data.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XlsVaksbg%253D&md5=04f0f93b2985e1a8680498477eacfbc0
    18. 18
      Lindorff-Larsen, K.; Piana, S.; Palmo, K.; Maragakis, P.; Klepeis, J. L.; Dror, R. O.; Shaw, D. E. Improved side-chain torsion potentials for the Amber ff99SB protein force field Proteins: Struct., Funct., Genet. 2010, 78, 1950– 1958 DOI: 10.1002/prot.22711
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Improved side-chain torsion potentials for the Amber ff99SB protein force field
      Lindorff-Larsen, Kresten; Piana, Stefano; Palmo, Kim; Maragakis, Paul; Klepeis, John L.; Dror, Ron O.; Shaw, David E.
      Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics (2010), 78 (8), 1950-1958CODEN: PSFBAF ISSN:. (Wiley-Liss, Inc.)
      Recent advances in hardware and software have enabled increasingly long mol. dynamics (MD) simulations of biomols., exposing certain limitations in the accuracy of the force fields used for such simulations and spurring efforts to refine these force fields. Recent modifications to the Amber and CHARMM protein force fields, for example, have improved the backbone torsion potentials, remedying deficiencies in earlier versions. Here, the authors further advance simulation accuracy by improving the amino acid side-chain torsion potentials of the Amber ff99SB force field. First, the authors used simulations of model alpha-helical systems to identify the four residue types whose rotamer distribution differed the most from expectations based on Protein Data Bank statistics. Second, the authors optimized the side-chain torsion potentials of these residues to match new, high-level quantum-mech. calcns. Finally, the authors used microsecond-timescale MD simulations in explicit solvent to validate the resulting force field against a large set of exptl. NMR measurements that directly probe side-chain conformations. The new force field, which the authors have termed Amber ff99SB-ILDN, exhibits considerably better agreement with the NMR data. Proteins 2010. © 2010 Wiley-Liss, Inc.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXkvFegtLo%253D&md5=447a9004026e2b93f0f7beff165daa09
    19. 19
      Maier, J. A.; Martinez, C.; Kasavajhala, K.; Wickstrom, L.; Hauser, K. E.; Simmerling, C. ff14SB: Improving the accuracy of protein side chain and backbone parameters from ff99SB J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2015, 11, 3696– 3713 DOI: 10.1021/acs.jctc.5b00255
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      ff14SB: Improving the Accuracy of Protein Side Chain and Backbone Parameters from ff99SB
      Maier, James A.; Martinez, Carmenza; Kasavajhala, Koushik; Wickstrom, Lauren; Hauser, Kevin E.; Simmerling, Carlos
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2015), 11 (8), 3696-3713CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      Mol. mechanics is powerful for its speed in atomistic simulations, but an accurate force field is required. The Amber ff99SB force field improved protein secondary structure balance and dynamics from earlier force fields like ff99, but weaknesses in side chain rotamer and backbone secondary structure preferences have been identified. Here, we performed a complete refit of all amino acid side chain dihedral parameters, which had been carried over from ff94. The training set of conformations included multidimensional dihedral scans designed to improve transferability of the parameters. Improvement in all amino acids was obtained as compared to ff99SB. Parameters were also generated for alternate protonation states of ionizable side chains. Av. errors in relative energies of pairs of conformations were under 1.0 kcal/mol as compared to QM, reduced 35% from ff99SB. We also took the opportunity to make empirical adjustments to the protein backbone dihedral parameters as compared to ff99SB. Multiple small adjustments of φ and ψ parameters were tested against NMR scalar coupling data and secondary structure content for short peptides. The best results were obtained from a phys. motivated adjustment to the φ rotational profile that compensates for lack of ff99SB QM training data in the β-ppII transition region. Together, these backbone and side chain modifications (hereafter called ff14SB) not only better reproduced their benchmarks, but also improved secondary structure content in small peptides and reprodn. of NMR χ1 scalar coupling measurements for proteins in soln. We also discuss the Amber ff12SB parameter set, a preliminary version of ff14SB that includes most of its improvements.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFequ7rN&md5=7b803577b3b6912cc6750cfbd356596e
    20. 20
      Lee, J.; Cheng, X.; Swails, J. M.; Yeom, M. S.; Eastman, P. K.; Lemkul, J. A.; Wei, S.; Buckner, J.; Jeong, J. C.; Qi, Y.; Jo, S.; Pande, V. S.; Case, D. A.; Brooks, C. L., III; MacKerell, A. D., Jr.; Klauda, J. B.; Im, W. CHARMM-GUI input generator for NAMD, GROMACS, AMBER, OpenMM, and CHARMM/OpenMM simulations using the CHARMM36 additive force field J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2016, 12, 405– 413 DOI: 10.1021/acs.jctc.5b00935
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      CHARMM-GUI Input Generator for NAMD, GROMACS, AMBER, OpenMM, and CHARMM/OpenMM Simulations Using the CHARMM36 Additive Force Field
      Lee, Jumin; Cheng, Xi; Swails, Jason M.; Yeom, Min Sun; Eastman, Peter K.; Lemkul, Justin A.; Wei, Shuai; Buckner, Joshua; Jeong, Jong Cheol; Qi, Yifei; Jo, Sunhwan; Pande, Vijay S.; Case, David A.; Brooks, Charles L.; MacKerell, Alexander D.; Klauda, Jeffery B.; Im, Wonpil
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2016), 12 (1), 405-413CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      Proper treatment of nonbonded interactions is essential for the accuracy of mol. dynamics (MD) simulations, esp. in studies of lipid bilayers. The use of the CHARMM36 force field (C36 FF) in different MD simulation programs can result in disagreements with published simulations performed with CHARMM due to differences in the protocols used to treat the long-range and 1-4 nonbonded interactions. In this study, we systematically test the use of the C36 lipid FF in NAMD, GROMACS, AMBER, OpenMM, and CHARMM/OpenMM. A wide range of Lennard-Jones (LJ) cutoff schemes and integrator algorithms were tested to find the optimal simulation protocol to best match bilayer properties of six lipids with varying acyl chain satn. and head groups. MD simulations of a 1,2-dipalmitoyl-sn-phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) bilayer were used to obtain the optimal protocol for each program. MD simulations with all programs were found to reasonably match the DPPC bilayer properties (surface area per lipid, chain order parameters, and area compressibility modulus) obtained using the std. protocol used in CHARMM as well as from expts. The optimal simulation protocol was then applied to the other five lipid simulations and resulted in excellent agreement between results from most simulation programs as well as with exptl. data. AMBER compared least favorably with the expected membrane properties, which appears to be due to its use of the hard-truncation in the LJ potential vs. a force-based switching function used to smooth the LJ potential as it approaches the cutoff distance. The optimal simulation protocol for each program has been implemented in CHARMM-GUI. This protocol is expected to be applicable to the remainder of the additive C36 FF including the proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and small mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVWru7nI&md5=1e986f2c205aca8fb80442bc9c95b229
    21. 21
      Reif, M. M.; Winger, M.; Oostenbrink, C. Testing of the GROMOS force-field parameter set 54A8: structural properties of electrolyte solutions, lipid bilayers, and proteins J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2013, 9, 1247– 1264 DOI: 10.1021/ct300874c
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21
      Testing of the GROMOS Force-Field Parameter Set 54A8: Structural Properties of Electrolyte Solutions, Lipid Bilayers, and Proteins
      Reif, Maria M.; Winger, Moritz; Oostenbrink, Chris
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2013), 9 (2), 1247-1264CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      The GROMOS 54A8 force field is the first of its kind to contain nonbonded parameters for charged amino acid side chains that are derived in a rigorously thermodn. fashion, namely a calibration against single-ion hydration free energies. Considering charged moieties in soln., the most decisive signature of the GROMOS 54A8 force field in comparison to its predecessor 54A7 can probably be found in the thermodn. equil. between salt-bridged ion pair formation and hydration. Possible shifts in this equil. might crucially affect the properties of electrolyte solns. or/and the stability of (bio)mols. It is therefore important to investigate the consequences of the altered description of charged oligoat. species in the GROMOS 54A8 force field. The present study focuses on examg. the ability of the GROMOS 54A8 force field to accurately model the structural properties of electrolyte solns., lipid bilayers, and proteins. It is found that (i) aq. electrolytes involving oligoat. species (sodium acetate, methylammonium chloride, guanidinium chloride) reproduce exptl. salt activity derivs. for concns. up to 1.0 m (1.0-m) very well, and good agreement between simulated and exptl. data is also reached for sodium acetate and methylammonium chloride at 2.0 m concn., while not even qual. agreement is found for sodium chloride throughout the whole range of examd. concns., indicating a failure of the GROMOS 54A7 and 54A8 force-field parameter sets to correctly account for the balance between ion-ion and ion-water binding propensities of sodium and chloride ions; (ii) the GROMOS 54A8 force field reproduces the liq. cryst.-like phase of a hydrated DPPC bilayer at a pressure of 1 bar and a temp. of 323 K, the area per lipid being in agreement with exptl. data, whereas other structural properties (vol. per lipid, bilayer thickness) appear underestimated; (iii) the secondary structure of a range of different proteins simulated with the GROMOS 54A8 force field at pH 7 is maintained and compatible with exptl. NMR data, while, as also obsd. for the GROMOS 54A7 force field, α-helixes are slightly overstabilized with respect to 310-helixes; (iv) with the GROMOS 54A8 force field, the side chains of arginine, lysine, aspartate, and glutamate residues appear slightly more hydrated and present a slight excess of oppositely-charged s.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Malde, A. K.; Zuo, L.; Breeze, M.; Stroet, M.; Poger, D.; Nair, P. C.; Oostenbrink, C.; Mark, A. E. An automated force field topology builder (ATB) and repository: version 1.0 J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2011, 7, 4026– 4037 DOI: 10.1021/ct200196m
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      An Automated Force Field Topology Builder (ATB) and Repository: Version 1.0
      Malde, Alpeshkumr K.; Zuo, Le; Breeze, Matthew; Stroet, Martin; Poger, David; Nair, Pramod C.; Oostenbrink, Chris; Mark, Alan F.
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2011), 7 (12), 4026-4037CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      The Automated force field Topol. Builder (ATB, http://compbio.biosci.uq.edu.au/atb) is a Web-accessible server that can provide topologies and parameters for a wide range of mols. appropriate for use in mol. simulations, computational drug design, and X-ray refinement. The ATB has three primary functions: (1) to act as a repository for mols. that have been parametrized as part of the GROMOS family of force fields, (2) to act as a repository for pre-equilibrated systems for use as starting configurations in mol. dynamics simulations (solvent mixts., lipid systems pre-equilibrated to adopt a specific phase, etc.), and (3) to generate force field descriptions of novel mols. compatible with the GROMOS family of force fields in a variety of formats (GROMOS, GROMACS, and CNS). Force field descriptions of novel mols. are derived using a multistep process in which results from quantum mech. (QM) calcns. are combined with a knowledge-based approach to ensure compatibility (as far as possible) with a specific parameter set of the GROMOS force field. The ATB has several unique features: (1) It requires that the user stipulate the protonation and tautomeric states of the mol. (2) The symmetry of the mol. is analyzed to ensure that equiv. atoms are assigned identical parameters. (3) Charge groups are assigned automatically. (4) Where the assignment of a given parameter is ambiguous, a range of possible alternatives is provided. The ATB also provides several validation tools to assist the user to assess the degree to which the topol. generated may be appropriate for a given task. In addn. to detailing the steps involved in generating a force field topol. compatible with a specific GROMOS parameter set (GROMOS 53A6), the challenges involved in the automatic generation of force field parameters for at. simulations in general are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtlOksrfO&md5=172110d6b41762f68c5238e7ea127e1d
    24. 24
      Koziara, K. B.; Stroet, M.; Malde, A. K.; Mark, A. E. Testing and validation of the automated topology builder (ATB) version 2.0: prediction of hydration free enthalpies J. Comput.-Aided Mol. Des. 2014, 28, 221– 233 DOI: 10.1007/s10822-014-9713-7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Testing and validation of the Automated Topology Builder (ATB) version 2.0: prediction of hydration free enthalpies
      Koziara, Katarzyna B.; Stroet, Martin; Malde, Alpeshkumar K.; Mark, Alan E.
      Journal of Computer-Aided Molecular Design (2014), 28 (3), 221-233CODEN: JCADEQ; ISSN:0920-654X. (Springer)
      To test and validate the Automated force field Topol. Builder and Repository (ATB; http://compbio.biosci.uq.edu.au/atb/) the hydration free enthalpies for a set of 214 drug-like mols., including 47 mols. that form part of the SAMPL4 challenge have been estd. using thermodn. integration and compared to expt. The calcns. were performed using a fully automated protocol that incorporated a dynamic anal. of the convergence and integration error in the selection of intermediate points. The system has been designed and implemented such that hydration free enthalpies can be obtained without manual intervention following the submission of a mol. to the ATB. The overall av. unsigned error (AUE) using ATB 2.0 topologies for the complete set of 214 mols. was 6.7 kJ/mol and for mols. within the SAMPL4 7.5 kJ/mol. The root mean square error (RMSE) was 9.5 and 10.0 kJ/mol resp. However, for mols. contg. functional groups that form part of the main GROMOS force field the AUE was 3.4 kJ/mol and the RMSE was 4.0 kJ/mol. This suggests it will be possible to further refine the parameters provided by the ATB based on hydration free enthalpies.
